{{Infobox Sailboat Specifications |image = |caption = The 2006 World Championships ([[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]]) |class_symbol = 14 |crew = 2 |loa = {{convert|4267|mm|ftin|abbr=on}}http://www.international14.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2&Itemid=20
(excludes bowsprit and rudder) |beam = {{convert|1040|mm|ftin|abbr=on}} (min)
{{convert|1830|mm|ftin|abbr=on}} (max) |hull = {{convert|74.25|kg|abbr=on}}
{{convert|72|kg|abbr=on}} (June 2011)
{{convert|70|kg|abbr=on}} (June 2013) |mastheight = {{convert|7626|mm|ftin|abbr=on}} |mainsailandjib= {{convert|18.58|m2|abbr=on}} |spinnaker = Unlimited (typically {{convert|32|m2|abbr=on}}) |d-pn = |rya-pn = |phrf = |updated = 12 August 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.international14.org/I14_Class_Rules.pdf |title=Rules of the International 14 Class |format=PDF |date=1 July 2007 |publisher=International 14 World Association}} |olympic = no }} The '''International 14''' is 14-foot double-handed racing [[Dinghy sailing|dinghy]]. The class originated in [[England]] in the early part of the 20th century. It is sailed and raced in many countries around the world and was one of the very first true international racing dinghy classes recognised by [[International Sailing Federation]]. It is a [[Development Class]] being controlled by a set of rules that allow for innovation and changes in hull and rig design as long as they fall within a set of specific limitations such as length, weight, beam, and sail area. The class has permitted its rules to be revised at various times in its history in order to keep the class at the forefront of dinghy racing development and can now best be described as an ultralight dual-[[Trapeze (Dinghy Gear)|trapeze]] [[sailing dinghy]] with large [[sail]] area. It is often raced with boats of similar design in [[one-design]], or non-[[Portsmouth handicap|handicap]] races. I14 sailors often give their boats unusual names. ''Knee Trembler'' and ''Shocker'' are two examples, but more abound. ==History== There are essentially four periods in the class' history: ===Displacement=== The [[Hull (watercraft)|displacement]] style, is also known as the "Before [[Uffa Fox]] Era". ===Planing=== [[Planing (sailing)|Planing]], which started with Uffa Fox and his deep-chested hulls, (boats named ''Avenger'', and ''Alarm'' were quintessential examples) which were broad aft with nearly straight buttocks, and narrow forward with a deep vee; another notable boat was ''Windsprite'', designed and built in cold-moulded plywood by Austin Farrar at Woolverstone, Suffolk, in the early 1950s, whose distinctive hull shape was emulated later in the [[International 505]] dinghy; ===Trapeze=== [[Trapeze (Dinghy Gear)|Trapeze]] [[Planing (sailing)|planing]], which came about decades later, when the trapeze was finally legalized in the class (it had been tried by Uffa and others in the 1930s but was banned); during this evolutionary period larger ballast tanks were permitted by the class rules that greatly improved the ability of crews to recover from capsizes; the period also saw the introduction of multi-chined boats that were radically different in hull shape from the earlier carvel-built and molded-plywood designs; ===Double-trapeze=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0 0 0 0.5em; font-size:90%;" ! Hull shape !! Date !! Designer |- | Ovington â1 || 1995 || [[Dave Ovington]] |- | Bieker â2 || 1996 || [[Paul Bieker]] |- | Morrison â7e || 1995 || [[Phil Morrison (yacht designer)|Phil Morrison]] |- | Morrison â8 || 1996 || Phil Morrison |- | Ovington â2 || 1997 || Dave Ovington |- | Bieker â2Z || 1998 || Paul Bieker |- | Bieker â3 || 1998 || Paul Bieker |- | Morrison â9 || 1998 || Phil Morrison |- | Ovington â3 || 1999 || Dave Ovington |- | Morrison 10 || 2000 || Phil Morrison |- | Bieker â4 || 2002 || Paul Bieker |- | Bieker â5 || 2005 || Paul Bieker |- | Beebe â2 || 2005 || [[Jason Beebe]] |- | Benji â1 || 2005 || [[Le Poisson]] |- | Bieker 6 || 2011 || [Paul Bieker] |} Double-trapeze super-planing, which has gone through a number of evolutions. The concept was developed in Australia and New Zealand, and influenced the design of the high-powered but lightweight [[18ft Skiff|Australian 18]]. This form of the boat really started to take form in the early 80's (but with only one trapeze) as the minimum weight was lowered and upwind planing became possible. Contemporary boats weigh as little as 165 lb, and have as typical equipment a retractable spinnaker pole, unlimited asymmetric [[spinnaker]] size, 200sq ft [[mainsail]] and [[jib]] area, a fully battened mainsail, an adjustable carbon rig, and a [[hydrofoil]] [[rudder]] that allows the boat to be trimmed fore and aft for different conditions, and as a drag reduction device. Since this is a development class, older boats have been obsoleted through rules changes. Many of the older boats still race in fleets of similar boats. Penultimates, also known as 'Pennies' are boats that feature much of the same technology as modern boats but are from prior to the 1996 merger between the International 14 and Aussie 14 classes. Classic boats are boats prior to 1984 and feature a symmetric spinnaker, single trapeze, and many feature cold molded wooden hulls. ==See also== * [[Jack Holt (dinghy designer)|Jack Holt]] * [[Phil Morrison (yachts)|Phil Morrison]] * [http://www.international14.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=30&Itemid=29 History of the Fourteens Part 4 - The Years of Challenge]. ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.international14.org International 14 Class website] * [http://www.international14.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=27&Itemid=29 The Class History] * [http://www.sailing.org/classes/I14.php ISAF International 14 Microsite] * [http://www.i14.ca Canadian i14 Fleet Website] {{International Sailing Federation Classes}} {{Sailing Dinghies and Skiffs}} [[Category:Dinghies]] [[Category:International Sailing Federation Members]] [[Category:Boats designed by Jack Holt]] [[Category:Two-person sailboats]] [[Category:Boats designed by Phil Morrison]] [[Category:Two-person sailboats]] [[de:Internationales 14-FuÃ-Dinghy]] [[fr:14 pieds (bateau)]] [[is:International 14]] [[it:International 14]]
